defs.docs: # Parity SCALE Codec

attributes.value: / Rust implementation of the SCALE (Simple Concatenated Aggregate Little-Endian) data format
/ for types used in the Parity Substrate framework.
/ SCALE is a light-weight format which allows encoding (and decoding) which makes it highly
/ suitable for resource-constrained execution environments like blockchain runtimes and low-power,
/ It is important to note that the encoding context (knowledge of how the types and data
/ structures look) needs to be known separately at both encoding and decoding ends.
/ The encoded data does not include this contextual information.
/ To get a better understanding of how the encoding is done for different types,
/ [SCALE Code page at the Substrate Knowledge Base](https://docs.substrate.io/v3/advanced/scale-codec/).
/ The codec is implemented using the following traits:
/ The `Encode` trait is used for encoding of data into the SCALE format. The `Encode` trait
/ * `size_hint(&self) -> usize`: Gets the capacity (in bytes) required for the encoded data.
/ This is to avoid double-allocation of memory needed for the encoding.
/ It can be an estimate and does not need to be an exact number.
/ If the size is not known, even no good maximum, then we can skip this function from the trait
/ implementation. This is required to be a cheap operation, so should not involve iterations etc.
/ * `encode_to<T: Output>(&self, dest: &mut T)`: Encodes the value and appends it to a destination
/ * `encode(&self) -> Vec<u8>`: Encodes the type data and returns a slice.
/ * `using_encoded<R, F: FnOnce(&[u8]) -> R>(&self, f: F) -> R`: Encodes the type data and
/   executes a closure on the encoded value.
/ Returns the result from the executed closure.
/ **Note:** Implementations should override `using_encoded` for value types and `encode_to` for
/ allocating types. `size_hint` should be implemented for all types, wherever possible. Wrapper
/ The `Decode` trait is used for deserialization/decoding of encoded data into the respective
/ * `fn decode<I: Input>(value: &mut I) -> Result<Self, Error>`: Tries to decode the value from
/   SCALE format to the type it is called on.
/ Returns an `Err` if the decoding fails.
/ The `CompactAs` trait is used for wrapping custom types/structs as compact types, which makes
/ them even more space/memory efficient. The compact encoding is described [here](https://docs.substrate.io/v3/advanced/scale-codec/#compactgeneral-integers).
/ * `encode_as(&self) -> &Self::As`: Encodes the type (self) as a compact type.
/ The type `As` is defined in the same trait and its implementation should be compact encode-able.
/ * `decode_from(_: Self::As) -> Result<Self, Error>`: Decodes the type (self) from a compact
/ The `HasCompact` trait, if implemented, tells that the corresponding type is a compact
/ The `EncodeLike` trait needs to be implemented for each type manually. When using derive, it is
/ done automatically for you. Basically the trait gives you the opportunity to accept multiple
/ types to a function that all encode to the same representation.
/ Following are some examples to demonstrate usage of the codec.
/ # // Import macros if derive feature is not used.
/ # // Import macros if derive feature is not used.
/ # // Import macros if derive feature is not used.
/ use parity_scale_codec::{Encode, Decode, Compact, HasCompact, CompactAs, Error};
/ The derive implementation supports the following attributes:
/ - `codec(dumb_trait_bound)`: This attribute needs to be placed above the type that one of the
/   trait should be implemented for. It will make the algorithm that determines the to-add trait
/   bounds fall back to just use the type parameters of the type. This can be useful for situation
/   where the algorithm includes private types in the public interface. By using this attribute,
/   you should not get this error/warning again.
/ - `codec(skip)`: Needs to be placed above a field  or variant and makes it to be skipped while
/ - `codec(compact)`: Needs to be placed above a field and makes the field use compact encoding.
/   (The type needs to support compact encoding.)
/ - `codec(encoded_as = "OtherType")`: Needs to be placed above a field and makes the field being
/ - `codec(index = 0)`: Needs to be placed above an enum variant to make the variant use the given
/   index when encoded. By default the index is determined by counting from `0` beginning wth the

defs.name: Input
defs.docs: Trait that allows reading of data into a slice.

attributes.value: / Trait that allows reading of data into a slice.

defs.name: remaining_len
defs.value: pub fn remaining_len(&mut Self) -> Result<Option<usize>, Error>
defs.docs:
Should return the remaining length of the input data. If no information about the input
 length is available, `None` should be returned.

attributes.value: / Should return the remaining length of the input data. If no information about the input
/ length is available, `None` should be returned.
/ The length is used to constrain the preallocation while decoding. Returning a garbage
/ length can open the doors for a denial of service attack to your application.
/ Otherwise, returning `None` can decrease the performance of your application.

defs.name: TypeInfo
defs.value:
pub enum TypeInfo {
    Unknown,
    U8,
    I8,
    U16,
    I16,
    U32,
    I32,
    U64,
    I64,
    U128,
    I128,
}
defs.docs: !INTERNAL USE ONLY!

attributes.value: / This enum provides type information to optimize encoding/decoding by doing fake specialization.

defs.name: Encode
defs.docs: Trait that allows zero-copy write of value-references to slices in LE format.

attributes.value: / Trait that allows zero-copy write of value-references to slices in LE format.
/ Implementations should override `using_encoded` for value types and `encode_to` and `size_hint` for allocating types.
/ Wrapper types should override all methods.

attributes.value: / Should be used when the encoded data isn't required.
/ This works by using a special [`Output`] that only tracks the size. So, there are no allocations inside the
/ output. However, this can not prevent allocations that some types are doing inside their own encoding.

defs.name: encoded_fixed_size
defs.docs: Returns the fixed encoded size of the type.

attributes.value: / Returns the fixed encoded size of the type.
/ If it returns `Some(size)` then all possible values of this
/ type have the given size (in bytes) when encoded.
/ NOTE: A type with a fixed encoded size may return `None`.

defs.name: WrapperTypeEncode
defs.docs: A marker trait for types that wrap other encodable type.

attributes.value: / A marker trait for types that wrap other encodable type.
/ Such types should not carry any additional information
/ that would require to be encoded, because the encoding
/ is assumed to be the same as the wrapped type.
/ The wrapped type that is referred to is the [`Deref::Target`].

defs.name: WrapperTypeDecode
defs.docs: A marker trait for types that can be created solely from other decodable types.

attributes.value: / A marker trait for types that can be created solely from other decodable types.
/ The decoding of such type is assumed to be the same as the wrapped type.

defs.name: append_or_new
defs.value:
pub fn append_or_new<EncodeLikeItem, I>(Vec<u8>, I) -> Result<Vec<u8>, Error>
where I: IntoIterator<Item = EncodeLikeItem>,
EncodeLikeItem: EncodeLike<Self::Item>, I::IntoIter: ExactSizeIterator
defs.docs:
Append all items in `iter` to the given `self_encoded` representation
 or if `self_encoded` value is empty, `iter` is encoded to the `Self` representation.

attributes.value: / Append all items in `iter` to the given `self_encoded` representation
/ or if `self_encoded` value is empty, `iter` is encoded to the `Self` representation.
/ let encoded = <Vec<u32> as EncodeAppend>::append_or_new(data, std::iter::once(&item)).expect("Adds new element");

defs.name: EncodeLike
defs.docs:
A marker trait that tells the compiler that a type encode to the same representation as another
 type.

attributes.value: / A marker trait that tells the compiler that a type encode to the same representation as another
/ E.g. `Vec<u8>` has the same encoded representation as `&[u8]`.
/     // Just pass the a reference to the normal tuple.
/     // Pass a tuple of a reference and a value.
/ The relation is not symetric, `T` implements `EncodeLike<U>` does not mean `U` has same
/ For instance we could imaging a non zero integer to be encoded to the same representation as
/ the said integer but not the other way around.
/ Not all possible implementations of EncodeLike are implemented (for instance `Box<Box<u32>>`
/ does not implement `EncodeLike<u32>`). To bypass this issue either open a PR to add the new
/ combination or use [`Ref`](./struct.Ref.html) reference wrapper or define your own wrapper
/ and implement `EncodeLike` on it as such:
/ impl<'a> core::ops::Deref for MyWrapper<'a> { // Or use derive_deref crate

defs.docs: Reference wrapper that implement encode like any type that is encoded like its inner type.

attributes.value: / Reference wrapper that implement encode like any type that is encoded like its inner type.
